abstract_summ: I would like to highlight the very important point, the first step of their algorithm for tracheal intubation of critically ill adults adapted for COVID-19 which states that staff must don full checked personal protective equipment (PPE).Extubation of patients with Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a high risk procedure for both patients and staff.IMPORTANCE: The COVID-19 pandemic is characterized by high transmissibility from patients with prolonged minimally- or asymptomatic periods, with a particularly increased risk of spread during aerosol-generating procedures, including endotracheal intubation.Shortages in personal protective equipment (PPE) and the high volume of contact staff have with COVID-19 patients has generated an interest in ways to reduce exposure that might be feasible especially during pandemic times and in resource limited healthcare settings.Some patients infected with the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) require endotracheal intubation, an aerosol-generating procedure that is believed to result in viral transmission to personnel performing the procedure.It is likely that requests for a tracheostomy in COVID-19 ventilated patients will soon come our way.
title_summ: Emergency tracheostomy during COVID 19 Pandemic in a head and neck surgical oncology unitManagement of Coronavirus Disease 2019 Intubation TeamsTracheostomy time‐out: New safety tool in the setting of COVID‐19Anesthesia and potential aerosol generation during Magnetic Resonance Imaging in Children with COVID‐19A framework for open tracheostomy in COVID‐19 patientsIntubation boxes for managing the airway in patients with COVID‐19Safe extubation during the COVID-19 pandemicAirway management of angioedema patients during the COVID-19 pandemicAerosol Box 2.0: Adjustments and Improvements Made in Mexico for Intubating Patients During the Coronavirus Disease 2019 Pandemic.A Surgical Safety Checklist for Performing Tracheotomy in Patients with Coronavirus Disease 19.Procedural sedation in the COVID-19 era.
